pullRequest.body:
This obviates the need for bumping timeout limits in `RingTheory.Kaehler` at the expense of explicit instances that Lean should easily be finding. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Can you please fix the conflicts? Thanks!

> Can you please fix the conflicts? Thanks!

Modulo the Rust errors (lol), it should build fine now though maybe not lint. I am still working on removing the hacky instances. If I don't succeed by early tomorrow, I will clean this up and mark it `awaiting-review`.
I guess this is ok for now. There are some very silly things transpiring still but it is materially better than the current situation.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speedcenter.informatik.kit.edu/mathlib4/run-detail/d628378f-a7da-42ac-bd3f-349766c958a1) for commit 3bd2a4b1954f858c1e28ac57feea7de83ac6f18f.
There were [significant changes](http://speedcenter.informatik.kit.edu/mathlib4/compare/8a8ae7f5-7f83-4994-84fb-0fd821345634/to/d628378f-a7da-42ac-bd3f-349766c958a1) against commit 0e849a1c15a758e9dc0394422175f72940aa99b1:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                  Metric         Change
  ================================================================================
- build                                                      maxrss           6.1%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Abelian                instructions     5.7%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Limits                 instructions    15.7%
+ ~Mathlib.FieldTheory.Finite.GaloisField                    instructions    -5.2%
+ ~Mathlib.FieldTheory.Normal                                instructions    -8.9%
+ ~Mathlib.FieldTheory.PolynomialGaloisGroup                 instructions   -10.3%
+ ~Mathlib.FieldTheory.SplittingField.Construction           instructions   -11.0%
+ ~Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Group.AddCircle                     instructions    -6.0%
+ ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.GroupCohomology.Resolution   instructions    -6.5%
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.ClassGroup                             instructions     5.6%
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.Ideal.Quotient                         instructions     5.3%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.Kaehler                                instructions   -38.6%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.Polynomial.GaussLemma                  instructions   -10.7%
```

It's probably worth commenting that (if I counted correctly) this reduces the number of `maxHeartbeats` bumps in this file from 6 to 0. A few days ago there were 16 and it was one of the slowest files in mathlib. Note also that @Vierkantor is working on getting ClassGroup compiling more quickly.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speedcenter.informatik.kit.edu/mathlib4/run-detail/cf8599d5-9dbf-4104-9315-f3c0677c847c) for commit 44e6d1550e7c2ed7120681259df69d658cddebea.
There were [significant changes](http://speedcenter.informatik.kit.edu/mathlib4/compare/8a8ae7f5-7f83-4994-84fb-0fd821345634/to/cf8599d5-9dbf-4104-9315-f3c0677c847c) against commit 0e849a1c15a758e9dc0394422175f72940aa99b1:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                  Metric         Change
  ================================================================================
- build                                                      maxrss           6.2%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Abelian                instructions     5.7%
- ~Mathlib.Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Limits                 instructions    15.7%
+ ~Mathlib.FieldTheory.Finite.GaloisField                    instructions    -5.2%
+ ~Mathlib.FieldTheory.Normal                                instructions    -8.9%
+ ~Mathlib.FieldTheory.PolynomialGaloisGroup                 instructions   -10.3%
+ ~Mathlib.FieldTheory.SplittingField.Construction           instructions   -11.0%
+ ~Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Group.AddCircle                     instructions    -6.0%
+ ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.GroupCohomology.Resolution   instructions    -6.5%
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.ClassGroup                             instructions     5.6%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.Kaehler                                instructions   -38.6%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.Polynomial.GaussLemma                  instructions   -10.7%
```

Three observations from the last run:
- fairly stable overall
- improvement in `Ideal.Quotient` probably due to removal of unnecessary `smul` fields in `Module.Basic`
- changing to `Mul.toSMul` from `Algebra.toSMul` seems to have little effect on performance in `Kaehler`
I think this is ready to be merged and further tinkering can be more focused in separate PRs

In this interest of granular benchmarking, my preference would be to split this PR in two:

* make the tweaks to the foundational instances as you do in this PR
* Add the shortcut instances and nothing else
Sounds good. I should be able to do the split in a few hours
!bench
Run cancelled. This is the only instances now.

One can compare [this run](http://speedcenter.informatik.kit.edu/mathlib4/compare/8a8ae7f5-7f83-4994-84fb-0fd821345634/to/cf8599d5-9dbf-4104-9315-f3c0677c847c) for the whole package to [this one](http://speedcenter.informatik.kit.edu/mathlib4/run-detail/ee1ac79b-3f4b-468d-9346-6d49c006c2b7) for the foundational instances. 

Taking a set difference, it looks like this will speed up `Kaehler` by ~40% and not do much else. Do we need another speed run before merging?
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/c4a82006-d57c-46ec-b027-763baa561c0c) for commit 066a7067ca2a618a70084f7cfef3de46bea8c4a5.
The entire run failed.
Found no significant differences.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/3238737f-7c9f-4754-ab5c-c41ab8028c65) for commit ea8b9af7b4a79e652c19c2c9dda7716b19364b2e.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/cb5e5617-5b72-48df-b4f0-0ff46215edde/to/3238737f-7c9f-4754-ab5c-c41ab8028c65) against commit a526f3ebfd15b267d66a4130c69e0b947f6ee63b:
```diff
  Benchmark                     Metric         Change
  ===================================================
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.Kaehler   instructions   -33.4%
```

Great work! Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  Build succeeded!

  The publicly hosted instance of bors-ng is deprecated and will go away soon.

  If you want to self-host your own instance, [instructions are here][instructions].
  For more help, visit [the forum].

  If you want to switch to GitHub's built-in merge queue, visit [their help page][gh].

  [instructions]: https://github.com/bors-ng/bors-ng#how-to-set-up-your-own-real-instance
  [the forum]: https://forum.bors.tech
  [gh]: https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/configuring-branches-and-merges-in-your-repository/configuring-pull-request-merges/managing-a-merge-queue



  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6270006412/job/17027300309)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6270006412/job/17027300499)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6270006412/job/17027300596)
You should be able to keep the new proof here rather than revert them
Oh. Sorry. Done.
Presumably this change is not needed?
No. I am blunt instrument. I'll restore it.
Done.
When was this removed?
In this PR during testing. It hurt.
We should delete these lines if they're dead code.

I'm not sure about this one: it looks like it's trying to make it clear that `Quotient.ringCon I` and `QuotientAddGroup.con I.toAddSubgroup` are the same relation under the hood, though maybe that's not actually effective.

As a sanity check it would probably be good to add an `example` checking that no diamond is formed with `Submodule.Quotient.addCommGroup`
This is a good point. I’ll probably revert for this PR after testing performance. Keep it streamlined
This `rfl`'s instantly so I'll include the example and leave as is

```suggestion
-- update: maybe not; removal causes timeouts
```
These curly brackets are a lean3-ism, right?
Don’t you need them with the `with` syntax?
Oh. *Those* braces

```suggestion
/- Note: Lean is slow to synthesize theses instances.
  Without them the endEquivDerivation' and endEquivAuxEquiv both have
  significant timeouts. -/
```
This basically was the case in mathlib3; at least, now that you wrote the type explicitly as `Derivation R S (Ω[S⁄R]) ≃ₗ[R] Derivation R S (KaehlerDifferential.ideal R S).cotangentIdeal`
Perhaps it should read “slower”
`Algebra.toSMul` is not supposed to ever be used (it has priority 0)
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/86ac6bf9dd506d502b43d848103031eaf1e8bc7c/Mathlib/Algebra/Algebra/Basic.lean#L344-L345
I don't understand why we deleted that, I think it should be restored (and I'd be interested to know how that affects performance)
Oops. I was on mobile before and didn't see the referenced code block. Might as well do a one-off to test performance implications.

> `Algebra.toSMul` is not supposed to ever be used (it has priority 0)

That’s what it finds naturally. I’m sure `Mul.toSMul` will be fine.

My understanding is that performance-wise, `Algebra.toSMul` is a bad instance because it shortcuts `Algebra.toModule`, `Module.toDistribMulAction`, `DistribMulAction.toMulAction`, and `MulAction.toSMul`. We shouldn't have transitive shortcuts, because then the number of instances we have grows massively.

I think @digama0 has expressed this opinion before?
That makes sense. `Mul.toSMul` keeps things below the timeout but seems (to the human eye) to elaborate more slowly
De-instanced `Algebra.toSMul` in #6219. Experiments indicate it would slow things down even more.

> I think @digama0 has expressed this opinion before?

I have expressed the opposite, basically lamenting that we can't have these instances because they would significantly decrease the cost of adding new intermediate classes if we could have shorter "expressways" which skip the intermediates and are preferred. Having them greatly increases the (already exponential) number of paths through the graph, but whether this is a crippling problem or not at all hinges rather delicately on details of the typeclass inference algorithm and we have gone back and forth between preferring and dispreferring transitive shortcut instances.
While the three `Module` instances don't seem terrible, this `SMul` and the three `IsScalarTower`'s seem like things Lean should find quickly.
Why a `theorem` and not `local instance`?
`defLemma` complained. Is there a better fix?

That sounds like a bug in `local instance` that we should report somewhere. I think a minimal repro is
```lean
local instance : Fact True := sorry
```

It isn't making that easy for me. But `local` is definitely the trigger. I am going to try to minimize in a bit. This has occurred for me before with `Fact` deep into the library. Maybe the import is messing things up? We'll see.
I think the problem is that `instance` is just always a `def`

This seems like a mwe:
```
namespace OhNo
local instance : Fact True := sorry
end OhNo
#lint
```
Indeed that is

It is a `def` with or without the local. Should [this](https://github.com/leanprover/std4/blob/e3c2be331da9ddeef7f82ca363f072a68d7210b3/Std/Tactic/Lint/Misc.lean#L96)
```lean 
    if (← isAutoDecl declName) || isGlobalInstance (← getEnv) declName then
```
be 
```lean
    if (← isAutoDecl declName) || (← isInstance declName) then
```
?
Hmm. Probably out of scope regardless

I didn't figure out how to read local instances in the scope that `#lint` works in. For now, it seems better just to `nolint` and bring the issue up on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/348111-std4/topic/local.20instances.20in.20.23lint).

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - fix (RingTheory.Kaehler): short cut instances to remove timeouts

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore (RingTheory.Kaehler): reasonable heartbeat limits
